ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Learned about all types of financial markets.
Learned about general mathematical models and real-world applications
knowledge about markets
Learned a great deal about financial institutions and how they work, not only in the US but around the world.
Institutional aspect of financial markets
Learned about the financial market and understanding different loans and other aspects
basics of financial markets
This course provides and overview on the ideas, technologies, methods, and institutions that permit society to manage risks and foster enterprise.
qualitative finance and a good understanding of financial institutions
Learned about financial markets - interests rates, repo market, stock market, options, bonds, pricing, etc. Quite similar to Econ 251.
Learnt a lot about responsible finance!
basic knowledge about finance and the financal system
financial markets
Intricate understanding of the history of financial markets and the various financial securities.
surveyed topics about finance and the markets. i found most of the topics interesting but didn't get to go too deeply into any single one.

A general understanding of the financial landscape. Although we did not spend too much time on any one topic, that was not the aim of the course anyway. We learned not just the lingo but also the workings of the financial world.
I developed a beginning understanding of financial markets and how they work
Discussions on risk weighting, behavioral finance, mortgages, options pricing, bond pricing, and philanthropy.
core concepts related to financial markets
Decent insight
Foundational knowledge regarding asset pricing and finance
Asset management, history about Robert Schiller and Eugene Fama, amortization schedule, bond prices, variance, standard deviation, CAPM, Sharpe ratio, etc.
barely any - maybe knowledge of basic financial formulas
Understanding of the markets
Not much really. Some understanding of financial markets but mostly how to teach myself an entire course with friends.
Quantitative and financial
I learned how financial functions function, operate, and are managed.
Thorough understanding of the US financial system and the financial instruments used in it.
mean variance analysis, bonds, mortgages, options

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: Interesting material (at least for me). Shiller is obviously super knowledgeable and would take about current events which I really appreciated and found interesting.

Weaknesses: So disorganized. The most disorganized course I have ever taken. Professor Shiller sometimes didn't know how to work Zoom. He won a Nobel Prize, he can't work Zoom? Even worse, lecture would end early sometimes because his laptop died. Unfortunately, the situation is only worsened by the TFs. They do not know what they are doing either, so there are multiple layers of disorganization that lead to confusion. There is so unified section each week, the TFs review what they want.

Strengths: Material was very interesting and relevant. Felt as though the workload was very manageable
Weaknesses: The lectures covered very little of the math that was present on psets and exams, meaning almost all of the graded material came from section which was quite odd.
Professor Shiller is obviously a very knowledgable man when it comes to the Finance world, but he's a terrible professor at teaching the subject of financial markets.
cool class.
Very clear explanations with recorded lectures made learning material easy.

Strengths: Professor Shiller's domain knowledge and stories
Weaknesses: Lecture was fairly dry, and included lots of historical details but less mathematical/conceptual explanation
Extremely difficult course to sit through. Brutal lectures
The content is interesting a d important

Strengths:
- Enough practice/TA guidance on quantitative aspects of the course

Weaknesses:
- Truly the worst professor-led lectures that I have watched. They were often completely irrelevant to course topics. We started with 60+ students attending zoom lectures. At the end, we were in the teens. None of my other classes saw this drastic of a dip in student participation. More time spent on random historical facts and personal anecdotes (irrelevant to financial market topics) than on quality content.
- Unreasonable grading time for exams. Second midterm took over a month to return to students. First midterm also took far longer than standard for an Economics midterm

How to improve:
- have a different professor teach this course
- lecture about relevant materials
- actually care
- significantly reduce the history section of the course. students did not sign up for a history course or to listen to the professor talk about how often a term was used over history--completely useless
- respect students' time. show up to lectures on time 
- choose TAs who want to teach

The strengths of this class is listening to Shiller's anecdotes, and experience, which is very cool. The weakness is that while the tangents can be super interesting, it is never clear from his lecture and from his slides, which topics are covered in the exam / related to the course.
great content, but low engagement. very few people came to lectures
It's a good course. Professor Shiller is great. Maybe the reading requirements for Fabozzi textbook should be clearler. The textbook is way too much to read.
Not much to improve! I think Professor Shiller has nailed the format for this class!

Strength: Prof Shiller is very knowledgeable about the subject.
Weaknesses: the lectures were all over the place and it was hard to keep track of what we needed to know for the exam

The course is intellectually interesting, but only fun when you have background knowledge in finance. For non-finance people or those who do not have any knowledge of finance, this could be difficult.

strength - interesting syllabus
weaknesses - poor coordination between TAs, professor often rambled, didn't have high engagement

The course was a recorded lecture and while this was very suitable for students, not many people would end up going to lecture. This was rather unfortunate and while I felt that the recordings were easier to take notes on, I would liked to have seen some degree of mandatory attendance, even if it was just for the professor.
This class could be improved if the lectures were more on topic with the tests.
Lecture could be better more geared toward problem sets

Weaknesses: Main lectures did not cover any quantitative material, only the sections covered them. A lot of it was self-studying.

Strengths: the material in the course is highly relevant and perhaps even necessary for those wanting to enter finance.
Strengths is the material and Robert Schiller. The weakness is it being on zoom, lecture was not on exams or psets .

Strength: section: good to go over skills needed for psets in section as they were not taught in lecture
Weakness: Lectures not engaging, no material from lecture was relevant on psets

Strengths: Making us read a textbook. Getting closer with my friends through trauma bonding.
Weaknesses: literally everything else. The professor's lectures were so terrible that I literally understood less after lecture than I did before, which I also know was true of my friends. The class was poorly structured - problem sets were unhelpful, and no solutions were ever uploaded for practice exams which makes literally no sense. The class might be the worst taught class I've taken ever, let alone at Yale.
- could be better structured
I think the course is very insightful but there could be more linkage between the content and the assessments.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Let's just get back to in-person classes.
was fine
Recorded lectures was the most helpful part.
Sections complement lectures

Recording lectures and sections was appreciated--2x speed makes the lectures partially bearable 

Besides that, the course did nothing to improve students' learning environment. Extremely low quality course

The professors should recieve some more training with zoom and PowerPoint because there were a few occasions where class was interrupted due to avoidable technical issues. I believe CTL should do more to help less tech savvy professors with this transition.
success: psets and discussion sections
More application-based class would have been more fun.
the lecture or section should be mandatory to increase engagement

As mentioned previously, the recorded aspect was both a success and a failure. It meant that more students would be able to effectively take notes and learn perhaps more efficiently, but it significantly decreased the student professor interaction.
It all worked fine, not much to improve on in that area.
Recorded lectures helped tremendously with managing time in a lecture course.
Decent job
Recorded lectures are a double edged sword: they make it more convenient for students to listen to lecture, but also make it such that people don't show up to the live virtual lecture.
Section was great, learned a bunch and carried me through course. I wish lecture was more value able to course material. Although Mr. Schiller was passionate .
poor - low engagement
Nothing succeeded to be honest. Actually, no. The recorded lectures were great because the rest of the class was so terrible that at least I could watch lectures to myself.
- having office hours for instructor
I think Professor Shiller did an excellent job with this aspect of the course.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: No

Only take this course if you are interested in the material. I was and I had an enjoyable time -- Financial Markets fascinate me! If you are thinking of taking this course because you heard Professor Shiller is super famous and smart, don't take it -- you'll hate it.
Yes, if you want to learn more about these topics. Professor Schiller is not a good professor so be prepared for that. The material is interesting but you will be teaching yourself almost all of it.
No because the Professor is all over the place with how he teaches the course.
Yes
Yes if they are an econ major or if they want to learn about financial systems. Very good overview of how they work.
Depends. It might be more worthwhile to take Econ 251, but this course can still be a good introduction to several finance-related concepts.
Yes for people interested to learn from Shiller's insights
Yes an interesting class and not terribly difficult.

NO! Absolutely not. Do not take this course under ANY circumstances. I do not care if you want "clout" from taking a course taught by a Nobel Prize winner. This is the worst taught class that I have ever taken--and that includes all of high school and middle school. I don't doubt that Professor Shiller is brilliant, but he is an AWFUL professor. His lectures have nothing to do financial markets. I saw more newspaper clippings and niche historical facts than actual economics/financial markets topics. So many irrelevant slides with some random Google Ngram. 80+% of students gave up and stopped going to live lectures. 

This basically was a self-taught course. The Fabozzi textbook actually talks about financial markets unlike Professor Shiller's lectures. Yale should be ashamed of themselves for offering such a low quality course. There is no way that the teaching team and Economics Department are oblivious to these glaring issues. 

TLDR: Worst taught class ever. Extremely low quality learning environment. Nice professor, but can't (or don't care to) teach. ZERO REDEEMING QUALITIES. Yale needs to get rid of this course or completely overhaul it. It is actively ruining Yale's reputation as an academic institution.

I would recommend this course to anyone interested in learning about finance from a broad perspective or anyone who wanted an introduction to ideas, methods, and institutions related to finance (on a more theoretical approach). If you are someone who is serious about pursuing a career in finance, then you should take ECON 251 instead as it is a lot more math heavy.
Yes, you will learn a lot of finance

Maybe. If you want to take a class with a Nobel Prize winning professor who is THE expert in financial markets then this is your class. You can always credit d if it doesn't work out. I thought the class was kinda disorganized at times.
I would if you wanna learn a little bit about finance with a social responsibility perspective.
No, it was difficult to keep track of what I was expected to learn.
Yes, definitely a good intro into finance.
yes if they want to an overview to the topics and if they want to take a course with a famous professor. no, if you want to learn about the topics deeply

I would, but know what you're getting yourself into. A lot of reading of the textbook, and a lot of learning the actual math through sections. Lecture is meant to be more eye-opening than instructive for psets.
No, the lectures and tests are almost operating on two different pages, takes a lot of self teaching to be ready to get good grades.

Professor Shiller is a phenomenal researcher, a powerful mind in economics, a pleasant and agreeable person, but not a good lecturer. The lecture content was interesting but rarely overlapped with the problem sets or exams. As such, all course learning came in the form of reading a textbook or finding online resources. I would not recommend it.
Maybe for Econ students
Yes, if they are finance oriented.
No. easy credit d fail i guess. But very disappointed considering it is taught by such an acclaimed professor.
No. Just take Econ 361 or Econ 251.
Recommend only for students with prior financial knowledge
Yes I think it gives a very good understanding of the financial institutions that are very important to our day-to-day lives.

If you are interested in learning about the basic principles behind portfolio building, the valuation of bonds and options, the US banking system, and the various global financial institutions, take this course. It will require a fair amount of self-preparation and reading of the textbook, but if this is a topic that you are passionate about, it will be all worth it.
No. It was horribly unorganized and had no real structure which made studying difficult. You were better off just reading the text book and nit even going to the lectures
